# Question

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here's a function in Julia that accomplishes the task you've described:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    lines = Vector{String}()
    current_line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = ""
        end
        if isempty(current_line)
            current_line = word
        else
            current_line *= " $word"
        end
    end

    if !isempty(current_line)
        push!(lines, current_line)
    end

    return lines
end
```

You can use this function to wrap a string into lines of a specified width. Here's an example of how you might use it:

```julia
text = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog"
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, 10)

for line in wrapped_text
    println(line)
end
```

This will output:

```
The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy
dog
```

The `wrap_string` function splits the input text into words, then iterates over the words, adding them to the current line until the line length exceeds the specified `text_width`. When the line length is exceeded, the current line is added to the list of lines and a new line is started. The function returns a vector of strings, each representing a line of the wrapped text.
